object.course_desc: While sexuality is often considered the most private and 'natural' of personal concerns, it is saturated with issues of social power, historical change, and public politics. This course offers a critical introduction to interdisciplinary studies of sexuality, focusing on history, theory, and cultural practice.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for DIST 2101 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing or permission of the Institute.
Lectures and discussion groups three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing or permission of the Institute.

object.course_desc: Historical and contemporary analysis of surveillance, security, and regulation of sexuality, race, class, and gender. Students will critically examine how ‘subversives’ were created through discourse and administrative logics such as policy and law.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Also listed as HUMR 2102.
Prerequisite(s): second year standing.
Lectures and discussions three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Exploration of ways that embodied categories of sex and gender, as well as desire are mediated through mainstream and alternative discourses of disability. Topics may include: crip theory, mental health issues, and LGBTQ sexualities.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing or permission of the Institute.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing or permission of the Institute.

object.course_desc: Students analyze sex, gender and sexuality as power relations within, and between nation-states comprising the Global North and South, as well as new knowledge created through national border crossings. Topics may include: Orientialism, colonialization, and diasporic identities.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing and SXST2101.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Examination of the archival turn in historical and theoretical perspective with an emphasis on sexuality, race, and gender as subjectivities in queer, trans, and colonial archives.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as HIST3102.
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing.
Seminar three hours a week.

object.course_desc: An interdisciplinary analysis of one or more topics in sexuality studies. The topics of this course will vary year to year and are announced in advance of registration.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): Third year standing and SXST2102 OR permission of the Institute of Women's and Gender Studies.
Lecture three hours per week. This course is repeatable as long as each topic is different.
object.course_prerequisites: Third year standing and SXST2102 OR permission of the Institute of Women's and Gender Studies.

object.course_desc: A study of selected issues in sexuality studies considered from an interdisciplinary perspective. The course may focus on any one, or combination of, sexuality studies in relation to history, theory, and/or cultural practice.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for DIST 4101 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): SXST2101 and fourth-year standing.
Seminar three hours a week.

object.course_desc: A critical approach to gender and sexuality by engaging in key debates and texts in the field of queer theory and studies.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): SXST2101 and fourth-year standing.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as WGST5102, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminar three hours a week.

object.course_desc: This seminar analyzes critically the existence and regulation of non-normative sexual attitudes, behaviours and practices. Topics may include: non-monogamy, sadomasochism, pornography.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing.
Seminar three hours a week.

object.course_desc: An interdisciplinary and intersectional approach to issues in the area of Sexuality Studies focusing on socio-economic relations (e.g. class location, consumption) and the ways they mediate sex, gender, and sexual subject formation and governance.        SXST 4101.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): fourth year standing.
Seminar three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Students engage with debates within sexuality studies and transgender studies regarding the interwoven relationships between gender, race, indigeneity, desire, bodies and ecological politics. Topics may include: climate change, gendered and sexualized landscapes, and speciesism.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing or by permission of the department.
Seminar three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing or by permission of the department.

object.course_desc: Critical examination of affective economies made in and through LGBTQ cultural production. Drawing from feminist, queer, trans and queer of colour critique, students will consider how queer affect, sentiment and emotions uniquely circulate in art and aesthetic objects.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing or permission of the Institute.
Seminar three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing or permission of the Institute.
